title: Leonardo da Vinci: The Renaissance Man
summary: Leonardo da Vinci painted, invented, and explored, showing how curiosity can stretch across many talents.
imageAlt: Sketchbook drawing of the Vitruvian Man by Leonardo da Vinci.
author: Jacob Sutanto
body: Leonardo da Vinci grew up in Italy more than 500 years ago. As a child, he watched birds and filled notebooks with sketches.
When Leonardo became an artist, he painted famous pictures like the Mona Lisa. He studied smiles, shadows, and how light dances on faces.
His curiosity didn't stop with paint. Leonardo designed flying machines, bridges, and even a diving suit. He took notes backward so only he could read them easily.
Leonardo loved learning about the human body. He carefully drew muscles, bones, and hearts to understand how people move.
His notebooks show that a curious mind can connect art, science, and invention all at once.

questions.prompt: What did Leonardo enjoy doing as a child?
questions.explanation: Leonardo loved to observe nature and draw it.

questions.prompt: Why did Leonardo write some notes backward?
options: He wanted to fit more words on a page.
He thought it was fun and private.
He didn't know how to spell.
questions.explanation: Writing backward made his notes feel like secret code.

questions.prompt: What idea ties all of Leonardo's work together?
options: Curiosity can connect art and science.
questions.explanation: Leonardo explored many fields because he was curious about everything.

prompts: Which of Leonardo's talents would you like to try?
How can curiosity help you solve a problem today?
